centralQuestion: Is Rent Control good for New York City?

reasons.description: Rent control protects vulnerable tenants from sudden rent increases and displacement.

sources.title: New York Times: 'Rent Control Is One Tool to Help Tenants Afford Their Homes. But It’s Not a Cure-All.'
Urban Institute: 'The Effects of Rent Control Expansion on Tenants, Landlords, and Inequality: Evidence from San Francisco'

reasons.description: Rent control helps keep neighborhoods stable and prevents community disruption.

sources.title: Pew Research Center: 'Rent Control: What Does the Research Say About Its Effectiveness?'
New York Times: 'For Some, Rent Laws Provide Security'

reasons.description: Rent control can slow gentrification and support racial and economic equity.

objections.description: Rent control reduces the incentive for landlords to maintain or improve properties, leading to deteriorating housing quality.

sources.title: Wall Street Journal: 'The Downside of Rent Control'
Manhattan Institute: 'Rent Control and Rent Stabilization as Forms of Regulatory Taking'

objections.description: Rent control can restrict the supply of rental housing and discourage new construction.

sources.title: Brookings Institution: 'What Does Economic Evidence Tell Us About the Effects of Rent Control?'
Washington Post: 'Rent control isn’t the answer to the affordable housing crisis'

objections.description: Benefits are often captured by higher-income or longer-term tenants rather than those most in need.

sources.title: Project Syndicate: 'The Return of Rent Control'

objections.description: Rent control can distort the housing market, leading to shortages, misallocation, and under-the-table payments.

sources.title: Economist: 'The case for and against rent control'

research.title: Rent Control and the Supply of Housing
research.description: This article reviews the economic literature on rent control and its impact on housing supply, finding significant evidence that rent control reduces the quantity and quality of housing.

research.title: The Effects of Rent Control Expansion on Tenants, Landlords, and Inequality: Evidence from San Francisco
research.description: Published in the American Economic Review, this paper analyzes a natural experiment in San Francisco and finds rent control helped tenants in the short-term but reduced rental housing supply and led to gentrification in the long run.

research.title: Housing Market Spillovers: Evidence from the End of Rent Control in Cambridge, Massachusetts
research.description: Examines the end of rent control in Cambridge and finds the policy had significant negative spillover effects on neighborhood investment and overall housing quality.

research.title: Rent Control: Do Economists Agree?
research.description: A survey of economists' views on rent control, published in Econ Journal Watch, finding overwhelming skepticism of rent control among professional economists.
